body:
paint me in trust - Chapter one: PROLOGUE

summary:

“Fifty.”
“Fifty what?”
Reed smirked. “Fifty dollars per day you take Cyrus out.”
“You’re a real asshole, you know that, right?”
“So, you’ll do it?”
“Yeah,” TJ bit his lip, thinking of his mom and sister. “Yeah, sure, I’ll do it.”

summary: Why you should write better women in your gay romance fic
body:
Why you should write better women in your gay romance fic

Let me preface this by saying I’m a man, and I apologize for what I’m sure will be the myriad mistakes I make in this piece

A long time ago I read a theory that proposed an interesting reason behind an interesting phenomenon. Why is it that young straight girls get so passionate about non-canon gay (for the purpose of this post, I am using gay to solely refer to gay males) pairings in fandoms? The theory had three parts:

  1. The male characters in these stories were often very fully written, with opinions, unique traits, and passion driving their actions, friendships and relationships
  2. The female characters in these pieces of media were often flat, with significantly less detail and uniqueness put into their characters, and were often nothing more than a goal for the male characters to achieve
  3. So, when looking for a relationship that had chemistry, satisfying conflict, passion—some real meat on its bones—these fans didnt land on the straight relationships, which often felt inevitable and maybe dull. They landed on the relationship between two male characters and used the passion, depth, and conflict found therein to also extrapolate attraction.

Now, I don’t know if that theory holds any water—one day I’d like to compare the frequency of non-canon gay fics in a fandom that has few strong female characters with one that is well known for its strong women (ATLA, maybe?)—but I always found it interesting. And it made me pay more attention to the presence of well written, well created female characters in the media I consumed.

But more importantly, it made me pay more attention to the female characters in the media I created. Though, full honesty, I know I’ve failed to accomplish my goal plenty of times. As someone who mostly writes gay romantic fics, I know full well how easy it is to just… ignore female characters.

Most often this isn’t malicious. It’s because 1) the protagonist of a gay story is inevitably male, and 2) the next most important character of this romance—the love interest—is also inevitably male, so 3) right off the bat your female characters are consigned to third place or lower. But thats just the obvious set of causes. Here’s some other, less obvious but more troubling ways I see women get the short shriff in gay stories:

  • They fall into the f*ghag/gay best friend trope, and exist only to have that relationship
  • They’re ignored because the author wants to prove that a gay character isn’t restricted to female friends
  • Their only role is to be the girlfriend/ex who gets in the way of the OTP gay romance (see: the icky tendency to force homophobic traits on female characters so they can be the villain of the love story)
  • They harbor a tragic, unreqitable love for the main gay character
  • They’re just generally unimportant to the story

Now, none of these character roles are necessarily horrible in their own own right—except for the third one, seriously, stop turning canon female love interests into homophobic villains just so you can have your dramatic gay story. But, in the aggregate of the way we write fiction, and especially fan fiction, it does a great disservice to representation of female characters. And I say ‘especially in fan fiction’ because nowadays we have a significantly richer selection of well rounded female characters that are too often flattened out, denied agency and their own goals, so that they can be nothing more than a stepping stone/support system for our gay main character. And it needs to stop.

Why is it that out of almost 1500 Andi Mack fics on AO3—most of which are Tyrus and Jyrus—probably less than 300 give Andi or Buffy any real importance as characters? They’re two beautifully created characters with traits, flaws, passion and quirks who all too often could be replaced with any generic human without really changing anything in the fraction of stories they do show up in. That’s just a waste.

Why does it matter? Well it should go without saying that representation is important, especially in a forum like fan-works which are generally aimed at younger, more passionate, more impressionable fans. Those interested in gay stories should be able to see good femal representation too. Also, too often gay men use the abuse and persecution they face as justification to turn around and spew invective at women and minorities, and we need to stop letting that invade and be supported by our writing.

Outside of the social reasons, incorporating well-rounded women with flaws, goals, and personalities into your stories will simply make those stories better. It will add to realism, it will widen your appeal, and it will improve your writing abilities. Learning to write through the voices and experiences of others will not only improve your storytelling, it will help you learn to become a better person. You might even gain empathy into the experiences of others.

Now does this mean that you need to rewrite that single-scene oneshot to force in a female character? No. Thats stupid. But for grander stories, with more characters and more scenes, question yourself when you’re not including women. Question yourself if the women you include aren’t as important to the story as the men. Correct yourself if you’re treating an entire gender as less important—or worse, villainous—just so you can have your men loving men.

And for the love of everything, stop leaving 50% of the global population out of your plot.

blog.name: heyoricohannah
blog.title: “I’m pretty petty and that’s a pity”

summary: Angsty jyrus with broken hearts crying and cavities worth of sweetness
question: Angsty jyrus with broken hearts crying and cavities worth of sweetness
answer:
Jonah’s always been a bit oblivious to the point of oblivion, but, this time, he has a feeling that he thinks he knows exactly what it is that’s going on.

He knows getting back together with Amber was a mistake. Not just because the two of them simply don’t belong together, but that because of this, Cyrus has been acting more distant than ever. And if anyone’s been the one to get Jonah to realize what’s most important, it’s Cyrus himself.

When Jonah was asked to meet him behind The Spoon, he knew he wasn’t going to be leaving as the same person who showed up.

“Why are you with her.” Cyrus has grown quite demanding and bitter about him and Amber. He’d like to get the confrontation over with before the rain drizzling down on them turns into a downpour.

“Cyrus-“

“Why.”

“None of your business!” Jonah’s cheeks flare and his voice raises.

“‘None of my business’?! Jonah you’re my best friend-“

“Am I?” Jonah spitefully laughs. “Am I really, Cyrus? ‘Cause last time I check you spend all your time with TJ.”

“What does he have to do with this, nothing, Jonah. Quit making it about everyone but yourself-“

“You think I’m that selfish?!” Jonah yells.

“Right now, yes!” Cyrus admits. “So what—I get a little busy so you decide to back to Amber, of all people? You know you can talk to me.”

“Right now, I think we both know that I can’t.” Jonah’s right fist is clenched, as is his jaw. “Clearly you don’t need to talk to me anymore. You have other people for that.”

“You’re ridiculous!” Cyrus screams as Jonah begins to walk away, which is just when the pressure of the rain grows intensely heavy. “Go back to your fake relationship. They’re all you’ve ever had, anyway.” He says the words that get Jonah to turn around.

“What’d you say?” As of right now, for all he cares, the rain isn’t even present.

“I said go back to your fake relationship. That’s all it is Jonah, it’s plastic. Amber, Andi, even Libby.”

“Don’t talk about Libby.” Jonah storms over back near him. His voices raises over the sound of the rain that tries to drown out both of their speech.

“Ah, see?! You’re not even over Libby so that’s why you’re jumping back into things with Amber!” Cyrus thinks he’s figured it out. “You can’t keep running, Jonah, not this time.”

“She’s not the one I’m not over…” Jonah cries aggravated tears, it being the only warmth he can feel at the moment.

“Andi?” Cyrus assumes. “‘Cause I hate to break it to you, but you guys were never meant to be.” Cyrus’ pettiness comes to show.

“But you and I were.” Jonah carefully says the words.

“Excuse me?” Cyrus doesn’t want to believe that he heard him correctly.

“We. Were. But I guess not anymore, huh? Guess it’s ‘cause I’ll never have my chance at a ‘real’ relationship.” Jonah forces himself to snap, eyes widening when seeing that he’s not the only one crying.

“Jonah what are you saying…” Cyrus wipes his tears.

“That maybe we had a chance, okay?! But it’s not worth it anymore. Come on. Look at me.” Jonah cries.

“Jumping from girl to girl. Clearly I don’t know how to handle myself. Let alone anyone else. And for a second there, I thought you liked me. All those months ago. Maybe you did but you stopped, not that I blame you ‘cause why bother keeping up. It’s why Andi ended things, and Libby. Soon enough Amber’s going to realize too. I’m a mess, Cyrus-“

“I never stopped!” Cyrus can’t take hearing him talk like that anymore. “Jonah I can promise you I never, stopped.”

In this moment Cyrus comes face to face with his prior denial.

“Ever. I was lying to myself when I thought I did. I was scared of losing you, and I did not want to lose you.” Cyrus’ voice trembles. “I would’ve rather lost myself. So that’s what I did, okay? It’s exactly what I did. But with you…I’m present! No one else has never made me feel so valued, or mattered, and…!” Several raindrops have poured down and joined the tears on his face.

Jonah could easily settle things right now. Not just settle, but officiate. Except there’s one thing that he needs to make happen, before he can do that.

“Jonah?! Jonah!” Cyrus yells after him once he sees him resume to walk away, this time making it front of the building, and right inside where he needs to be.

This is the first and last time he’ll leave Cyrus feeling alone.


He was hoping maybe Cyrus would’ve waited. Maybe even come in due to all the rain, and see things for himself. But, things took longer than expected, and when Jonah went back out to check, he was gone, which a part of him deeply understood, and not just because of the weather.

Not only does he find Cyrus, but Cyrus finds him. Standing on the back porch step of his home, outside in the continuously pouring rain. Rubbing at his tearful eyes, he unlocks and opens the door, moving away so Jonah can step inside, staring him down as he wipes the tears from his face.

His dire expression demands that he explains himself as to how, and most importantly why.

“I broke up with Amber…”

Chest just about closing in around his heart, Cyrus gasps out a breath, his eyes widening and watching as Jonah steps over directly across from him.

“You were right, Cyrus.” He states. “With Andi, Amber, even Libby…Nothing felt real. But with you, everything is. Realer than anything I could ever imagine.”

This is enough to get Cyrus to kiss him, which doesn’t take long to turn either of them sensually energetic, the two moving onto the couch and enjoying not only themselves but one another, as Jonah stays stuck on top of him while returning his kisses repeatedly, the both of them trying to keep it steady and evenly paced, feeling as if maybe they’ve manipulated the concept of time.

If there’s any moment to be stuck in, they’d surely wouldn’t mind if it were this one.

Eventually growing worn out, they come to a stop, Cyrus placing his head on top of Jonah’s chest and enjoying with him both the sound of the calming rain outside, and the view of the ceiling above.

“What’re you thinking.” Cyrus softly asks to Jonah.

“Hm?” Jonah looks down into his eyes and smirks. “Mm.” He squeezes onto his hand, momentarily glancing at the sight before looking back to him.

“That—things between us probably should’ve happened a lot sooner.” He giggles.

“Yeah.” Chuckling, Cyrus agrees. “I’m just glad it did…” He grins and climbs directly above him, having Jonah return his smile.

“Can I be honest with you…” Jonah whispers, lightly caressing his face and running his fingers through his hair.

“I encourage it.” Cyrus answers, heart growing heavy at the intense look Jonah sends deep into his eyes, and at the long pause that unexpectedly lasts between them.

“I love you.”

Cyrus laughs with relief, heart now hammering out of excitement and staying put in his chest.

“I love you too. Y’know…If I’m being honest.” He smirks.

“Are you?” Jonah jokes.

“I’m a man of my word.” Cyrus promises, sitting them up across from each other and lightly touching the center of his nose.

“One of the many reasons why I love you so much.” Jonah states, making them both giggle and move in towards each other even closer. “Yeah?” Their knees now connecting, Cyrus pushes Jonah’s hair back and lightly ruffles it around.

“Mm-hm.” Jonah shuts his eyes and goes in for a kiss that Cyrus instantaneously accepts.

If they were to accumulate the manipulation of time, they wouldn’t dare mess with it, since they know that the best thing they can do at this point, is go seamlessly forward.

Which, after all, is their best, and only choice.

i don't know where i was going with this so i might as well just post it
summary:
"Nothing feels heavier than unsaid words."
Andi reads that on a battered old sign in a thrift store one day and it sticks with...
body:
“Nothing feels heavier than unsaid words.”

Andi reads that on a battered old sign in a thrift store one day and it sticks with her. She can relate to feeling the weight of thoughts she cannot voice, it’s such a common thing for her.

“Nothing feels heavier than unsaid words.”

She thinks of the saying when she’s fighting with her parents and doesn’t know how to turn her emotions into words properly. It comes to the forefront of her mind when Buffy or Cyrus do something especially nice for her and she doesn’t know how to articulate how grateful she is for them. When Cece gives her a look of disapproval, the thought is there in the back of her mind.

Words weigh heavy on her chest and her tongue but they continue to go unspoken because she cannot bear to say them out loud. However, she doesn’t realise how true the saying is until she meets Amber.

Amber is one of the most beautiful girls Andi has ever seen. Her hair is soft and falls across her shoulders like a shimmering waterful. When she laughs her eyes light up and she seems to forget the world around them entirely. Her voice, her smile, her… her everything, is perfect. Amber is perfect, even in the face of all her imperfections. She makes Andi’s heart beat doubletime.

She wants to tell her this. When she heard Amber put herself down she wants to stand up and list all the reasons she makes Andi’s day brighter, tell her how much she means to her, but the words get stuck in her throat. She doesn’t know how to tell her… wouldn’t even know where to begin with explaining Amber might as well have hung the moon as far as she’s concerned, so she keeps it to herself. The words weigh heavily on her chest and she doesn’t know what to do about it.

“Nothing feels heavier than unsaid words.”

Yes, that seems about right to Andi.

summary: do you think andi mack might actually move to being a Disney + exclusive?
question: do you think andi mack might actually move to being a Disney + exclusive?
answer:
No offence - but my opinion on this topic really hasn’t changed that much over the several months I’ve spoken about it. So in the future, please just check the “disney plus” tag on my blog to read what I’ve said about it in the past. 

Moving Andi Mack to Disney+ would be a smart move on Disney’s part. If it were completely up to me, I believe the smartest concept would be to put the past seasons on Disney+ once it launches, continue the extended production hiatus so the kids can finish up their other projects, re-launch the series as a child/family-friendly high school series, stop releasing episodes early on DisneyNOW, air the episodes at their regular time slot on Disney Channel, and then make them immediately available on Disney+ and Hulu after the cable airing. 

I actually think that with the right promotion and slight rebranding, Andi Mack would have the potential to continue beyond four seasons if they wanted to, I just doubt that Disney would commit to that. But right now so much of this is beyond our reach. The financial aspect of production is probably the biggest element when it comes to renewal, and unfortunately that is something that we have absolutely no influence on at this point. My Disney+ idea is great as far as increasing viewership, and increasing potential longevity of the show itself - but it doesn’t solve all of the problems when considering renewal. 

So as always, my answer is: I don’t know. But I think it would be a smart risk to take. Especially considering how much LGBTQ content Disney seems to be gearing up for the launch of Disney+. Between HSM: The Musical, Four Dads, and Leah on the Offbeat, plus all of the existing content Disney holds the rights to - it’s looking like they could have their very own “LGBT” category like Netflix does - and that alone will draw in so many viewers for the first 3 seasons of Andi Mack… it would be a shame to not take advantage of that, really.
